awd_titl_txt: UNS Collaborative Research: Optimizing Microfilter Productivity During Water Treatment: Modeling and Experimental Verification
awd_abstract_narration:
1510743 
Cogan 

1510526 
Chellam 

This collaborative project results from the excellent filtered water quality of microfiltration membranes which are increasingly implemented for environmental and industrial water/wastewater separations. Tremendous effort has been spent studying fouling mechanisms during microfiltration; however, membrane fouling control by backwashing and air scouring remain largely unexplored topics. This work builds upon the PIs significant past collaborations to develop models of membrane processes. The proposed research will yield a rigorous mathematical framework along with systematic experimental validation to maximize microfiltration water productivity by maintaining high flux with periodic regeneration and electrocoagulation/flocculation pretreatment. This project provides a unique perspective to train students at all levels in multidisciplinary studies and broadening participation in science and engineering. 

The proposed research represents a synergistic collaboration between an experimentalist with expertise in membrane filtration and a mathematician with long-term expertise in modeling, fluid dynamics, and optimal control to make potentially transformative contributions to fouling control. The PIs tackle the problem of maximizing the cumulative volume of surface water filtered by hollow-fiber microfiltration incorporating periodic regeneration using optimal control theory. This study also includes sensitivity analysis and data assimilation, complementary mathematical processes used to quantify aspects of variability that arise in both theoretical and experimental studies due to underlying stochastic processes, uncertainty in measurements, or errors in approximations. Complementary laboratory measurements are aimed at generating necessary data for model validation as well as novel interfacial chemical characterization, to discern the sequence of mechanisms that lead to (ir)reversible fouling. Additionally, experiments and modeling will encompass Lake Houston water pretreated using an innovative electrochemical process, namely electrocoagulation with sacrificial aluminum electrodes. The underlying mathematical approach requires specific experimental measurements to determine sensitivity rankings for parameters (and hence physical quantities), statistical likelihood estimates for parameter distributions, and advanced optimal control analysis. Similarly, the experimental approach requires predictions such as key parameter regimes to explore, specific areas of uncertainty that can be reduced, and validation experiments to consolidate the real-world behavior with the mathematical predictions. This is facilitated by seamless collaboration, established over the past seven years or so, that brings together substantial experience on experimental and theoretical aspects to the project. Input will also be obtained from external stakeholders including a membrane manufacturer (Pall Corporation) and a water purveyor (Orange County Water District) who will provide hollow fibers as well as operational data from their long-term pilot-studies. They will also evaluate our methods and results to attempt to increase the productivity during low-pressure membrane filtration.

por.por_cntn:
The global water scarcity is well-documented, with approximately 4 billion people experiencing severe shortage at least one month annually and over 500 million experiencing it throughout the year.  This problem is only predicted to worsen with 700 million people facing displacement due to intense water scarcity in the next decade.  Since a third of the world's largest groundwater basins are distressed and excessive groundwater utilization causes ground subsidence that worsens flooding and damages the built infrastructure, a logical approach to produce drinking water is to better utilize our surface water sources and to implement potable water reuse.

Purifying impaired waters to a sufficient level so as to make them drinkable require advanced technologies such as membrane filtration.  In this project, we targeted microfiltration, which operates at relatively low pressures making it inexpensive and therefore potentially easier to implement.  However, these filters can clog rapidly when particles, microorganisms, and organic compounds in the influent water accumulate on its surface.  To date, the scientific community does not have a comprehensive understanding of these processes and associated mechanisms by which colloidal, organic, and biological fouling is initiated and progresses over long time scales.  This knowledge gap was the focus of our research wherein we collaboratively performed mathematical modeling and laboratory experiments.  Modeling was mostly performed at Florida State University using a first-principles approach to quantify deteriorations in membrane performance and to develop numerical/computational methods to optimize performance.  A crucial aspect of our mathematical analysis is that we also tackled uncertainties in modeling and parameter estimation.  Importantly, we collaborated with the largest indirect potable water reuse facility in the world located in Orange County in southern California.  We successfully analyzed and quantified fouling of their filter banks using our relatively simple model.

All bench-scale tests were performed at Texas A&M University and were designed to evaluate fouling mechanisms during microfiltration of wastewater after it underwent secondary treatment (i.e. activated sludge).  All tests were run with a commercially available hydrophobic, hollow-fiber polymeric membranes graciously provided to us by Pall Corporation using samples collected at our local wastewater treatment plant.  We investigated both hydraulically reversible and irreversible aspects of fouling during operationally by monitoring the increasing pressures necessary to maintain a constant and predetermined flux.  We designed and fabricated two types of custom prototypes in our laboratory one that operates at pressures above that of the atmosphere and another that is submerged in water and operates under a vacuum (photographs are uploaded separately).  Through spectroscopy and electron microscopy, we identified a two-step mechanism wherein relatively hydrophobic molecules in the feed water initial bound to the membrane, which served as platform for further deposition of comparatively more hydrophilic molecules with progressive filtration.  Foulants deposited both on the membrane surface and inside its pores worsening backwashing efficiency.  We also investigated pre-chlorination of the wastewater as a method to reduce fouling.  In these experiments, we observed that fouling was actually exacerbated at low chlorine dosages and higher chlorine concentrations were necessary to reduce fouling.  This was because chlorine cleaved organic molecules and changed their polarity thereby changing the interactions with membrane surfaces.  We successfully explained these phenomena using the extended Derjaguin-Landau-Verwey-Overbeek theory.  We also investigated the phenomenon of membrane aging where the performance deteriorates over the long-term.  Novel techniques were developed to investigate this less-studied aspect of microfiltration in the laboratory.  In this aspect of our research, membrane surfaces were characterized in detail using infrared spectroscopy.  Results demonstrated that progressive accumulation of foulants, identified as proteins, polysaccharides, and humic-like materials following cyclical fouling (adsorptive fouling) and chemical cleaning were primarily responsible for gradual reductions in permeability and increased fouling propensity. 

Funding was largely used to fully support a doctoral student who recently completed his dissertation.  Another Ph.D. student was partially supported as were several undergraduate students who were taught research procedures, laboratory protocols, data analysis/interpretation techniques, and literature reviews. 

Separately, lesson plans were created for fourth graders focusing on water quality and treatment.  This included coagulation, flocculation, and filtration to remove turbidity and color as visual indicators of purity.  We visited elementary schools once or twice a semester to teach different sets of students to perform these hands-on experiments in their classroom before COVID concerns cancelled in-person visits.  We also participated in ?Career Day? at Hearne Elementary, a rural school to inform students and teachers the value of a STEM education and all engineering careers.  We also trained a science teacher (Patrick Goertz) from St. Dominic Savio Catholic High School in Austin, Texas on water treatment processes including electrocoagulation and membrane filtration with the expectation that he includes these concepts in his classes.
